content.webTitle: AFLW: Cats' inaugural captain Melissa Hickey seeks triumph after adversity

fields.headline: AFLW: Cats' inaugural captain Melissa Hickey seeks triumph after adversity
fields.bodyText: “I’ve just got my new diary for the year and it draws out your goals. It’s a pretty cool time of year to reflect on the year that’s been. It becomes a launching pad of what’s to come.” Over coffee in a Brunswick cafe, AFLW player Melissa Hickey shows me the pages of her 2019 diary. “This is a really cool diary, I had the same one last year. It gives you each week to plan. You’ve got your priorities, your weekly goals, gratitude and your habits you’re trying to bring in for the week. It kind of gets you to check yourself. It’s a values based thing, it makes me think about what I prioritise. Footy is always number one.” The 2018 AFLW season was cruel to Hickey. She suffered a devastating ACL injury and was forced to watch her Melbourne Demons narrowly miss the opportunity to play in the AFLW grand final from the sidelines. As she sets her goals for 2019, her year couldn’t look more promising. A new club, coming back strong from injury and as she prepares to take the reins in her new role as the inaugural captain of the Geelong Cats AFLW team, and she’s already ticking off some of her goals in her diary. “I really wanted to be the captain or vice-captain at Geelong, that was almost like a goal I set for myself, so in some ways I was doing it from just being me from day one at the club. I just hoped that resonated with the playing group.” As Hickey enters her tenth year of playing the game, she’s self-aware and astute to the role she wants to play at Geelong from the lessons she’s learned in her football journey. “I hope my style of leadership is to really try to empower people. I think I was a lot more individually focussed in the past about my goals, a premiership was always number one, but then I wanted to get All Australian and Best and Fairest and stuff like that. That doesn’t drive me so much anymore, it would be amazing, but it’s not really my focus. “There’s an extra sense of pressure there now because the captain has to perform. First and foremost you have to be playing well and I’m probably someone who leads by example in that regard. I don’t think it’s going to be my pre-game speeches that get us over the line!” The last 12 months have also been a time of personal transition and growth for Hickey whose challenges were not just restricted to the field. In some tough times, she’s been able to develop her resilience as she focusses on the next stage in her football career and her life. She’s also learnt that no matter how many goals and plans you can write down in your diary, you can’t control everything. “When my long-term partner and I broke up, before that I thought I had everything planned out. Everything was pretty set and it was almost like, someone used this analogy with me, that you’ve got your jigsaw puzzle and you’re starting to put all the pieces together and then someone’s come along and whacked it and so all the pieces kind of fell out.” Hickey is excited to be looking forward to the possibilities a new year can bring. “Now it’s kind of cool to think, well I’ve almost got a blank canvas again and think, what do I want to do? What actually feels right for me and what fulfils me which sometimes you can lose in a long-term relationship. “I feel like I’ve had so much growth because I’ve had so many challenges and been uncomfortable and then I did my knee. So it’s been a year of learning, sometimes you just can’t control things, shit just happens and then you have to have the ability to bounce back from that or find the meaning in that. “It’s a yin and yang pull, it’s chaos and order. You can’t always have order, sometimes you need to be in chaos.” It is this perspective and emotional intelligence that will serve Geelong well by having Hickey as captain. Her experience in overcoming adversity has given her many tools to lead and inspire but it has also allowed her to identify how things that many might see as small or innocuous can contribute to someone else’s resilience toolkit. “I’m working with one of the girls at the club to try to get her to accept compliments, just to say, ‘thank you’ if you get a compliment rather than deflecting it. Because there are stepping stones from that, self-belief comes from that. I look at her and think she’s already a good footballer, just wait until she believes she is.” These small moments, these interactions come from someone who was a leader long before they were given a captaincy title and despite having the captaincy as one of her goals, she’s aware of her reasons for wanting it and why that’s so important. “I read and listen to a lot of stuff on leadership and they say that if you’re leading for the purpose to be the leader then you’re missing the point. You lead to help out your mates or because it’s the right thing to do and if you’re expecting anything back, you’re not in it for the right reasons.” As we finish up our coffee and I begin to make my way home, Hickey says she is going to stay at the cafe and take some time plan her week and reflect on what’s been and what’s to come. “That’s just kind of my learnings from a full on twelve months. I can quite honestly say that something I thought at the time was one of the worst things to happen to me is now probably almost the best thing to ever happen to me because I’ve gone back to being more who I am, back to my real self. I’ve prioritised friendships and I’ve got a lot more love in my life from that now and that freedom to be like, well, what do I want to do with my life? And you could meet someone next month who is the most incredible person in the world and that’s exciting, and then footy is just there tracking along.” I ask just as I’m about to leave: “Does footy make everything better?” She smiles. “Yeah it does. It’s so cool like that.”
